instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio
threads.message:
No PRAM chime, no output device detected, no corrosion.  Theres a dent around the audio jack but thats probably a symptom of a frustrated consumer unlikely the cause.
I don't have the BoardView for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> but <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is close so thats what I'm going by.

<RESISTOR>R6200</RESISTOR>: 3.3V
L6200:  5V 

Any idea where to go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio
threads.message: Voltage on <CAPACITOR>C6212</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6217</CAPACITOR>? How big is this dent?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio
threads.message:
No Title

<CAPACITOR>C6212</CAPACITOR> P1: 3.3V, P2: 0V
<CAPACITOR>C6217</CAPACITOR> P1: 4.5V, P2: 0V

Dent is pretty small

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Audio
threads.message: There should of course be voltage on those 2 caps. Should not be hard to figure this one out.
